author: ralexstokes
content: i think a helpful way to think about it is that we want L1 to be the "ground truth" for what has happened on the network. we get this "ground truth" by the process of consensus. there is a bit of "timeliness" to the protocol in that in terms of *consensus*, validators only need a lens/focus/cursor over the *recent* state of the protocol

author: ralexstokes
content: part of the consensus outcome for validators on ethereum is that they will agree on the *availability* of some data (organized into shards but thats almost an implementation detail at this point)

author: ralexstokes
content: we design the consensus protocol such that you have crypto-economic guarantees towards trusting what the output of the consensus process is (e.g. my eth balance at block N is X wei) and these guarantees are the "security" "protecting" your on-chain assets.

author: ralexstokes
content: if you as a user are following the chain, then you can also follow this consensus process and know what is going on, along with everyone else

author: ralexstokes
content: and, if this is all you need to do, you don't need any history so far... and to that end i don't think we should view shards as "persistent storage"

author: ralexstokes
content: it is not sustainable for consensus nodes to hold such a persistent storage as it will just grow over time

author: ralexstokes
content: and there are certainly ongoing research efforts towards changing the guarantees of the network wrt history

author: ralexstokes
content: now, _separately_ to consensus, you may need network history for some reason, but i'd frame that as a separate question to the working of the consensus protocol

author: ralexstokes
content: one example i can point you to right now is r&d on the portal network, which is prototyping some ideas around decentralized network storage
